sage.model.loader

Class OBJLoader

  • java.lang.Object
    • sage.model.loader.OBJLoader
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IModelLoader

    public class OBJLoader
extends java.lang.Object
implements IModelLoader
    This class defines a Content Loader for Wavefront "OBJ" files. Typical usage is to instantiate the class and then invoke the loadModel(String) method, passing it a String giving the OBJ filename; loadModel() returns a TriMesh object representing the model described in the OBJ file.

    The loader assumes that the OBJ file always contains exactly three geometric coordinates on 'vertex' ('v') commands, always contains exactly three normal components on 'vn' commands, and always contains exactly two texture coordinates on all 'vt' commands; an exception is thrown if these constraints are not met. (It's syntactically legal for an OBJ file to have 1D or 2D geometric vertex values and/or to have 1D or 3D texture coordinate values, but the current implementation of OBJLoader does not support these variations; it requires 3D geometry and 2D texture mapping in order to comply with similar constraints in the TriMesh class.) Note that only 'v' commands are required in a given OBJ file; 'vt' and 'vn' commands may be omitted (but if present they must comply with the above rules).

    All polygons ('faces' in OBJ terminology) defined in the OBJ file as having more than three vertices are "triangularized" (converted to an equivalent set of triangles) by the loader. Note that the triangularization algorithm assumes all polygons (faces) are convex; the results of loading an OBJ file with non-convex faces are unpredictable.

    Currently the following OBJ file commands are recognized by the OBJLoader; any other commands (or illegal text) in the specified OBJ file generate a warning message and are otherwise ignored:

    • v
    • vt
    • vn
    • f
    • mtllib
    • usemtl
    • # (indicates a line containing a comment)

    If the OBJ file defines a material library (using the 'mtllib' command), the OBJLoader constructs a new OBJMaterial object for each material defined in the material library and fills the material object with the material information from the material library. The TriMesh returned by loadModel(String) includes the collection of any such materials defined by the 'mtllib' command. If the materials include a specification of texture mapping (e.g. using the map_Kd OBJ material library command), the texture file name will be stored in the corresponding material object (however, see the note below regarding application of texture mapping).

    If the OBJ file assigns materials to faces (using the 'usemtl' command), the diffuse component of the assigned material is used as the color of each of the vertices defining the triangles making up that face. If no material is assigned to faces, OBJLoader assigns the colors Red, Green, and Blue to consecutive vertices of each triangle, producing triangles which are color-interpolated across their surface.

    Note: the current implementation of OBJLoader expects all material libraries to reside in a folder named materials. The materials folder must be in the program start-up directory (that is, its location is relative to the program rather than to the model being loaded).

    Note that while the OBJLoader correctly loads and returns texture coordinates in the resulting TriMesh object, it does not directly implement texture mapping for that object. Specifically, it is the responsibility of external code to obtain from the TriMesh object any associated texture image file, to load, bind, and enable the specified texture image, and to arrange that the assigned texture coordinate values are passed to the underlying graphics API at render time.

    By default the OBJLoader does its work silently (in the absence of warnings or errors). Invoking setShowWarnings(boolean) specifying false disables the display of warning messages. The default value for showWarnings is true. Invoking setVerbose(boolean) specifying true causes the OBJLoader to output tracing information regarding its actions. The default value for verbose is false.

    See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_.obj_file and http://www.martinreddy.net/gfx/3d/OBJ.spec for information about OBJ format.

    Author:
    John Clevenger
    See Also:
    TriMesh, Material, OBJMaterial

      TriMesh loadModel(java.lang.String modelFilename)
      loadModel receives a String, assumed to be the name of a file containing a 3D model in WaveFront OBJ format; it reads the OBJ file and returns a TriMesh object containing the OBJ model data.

      Enables/disables the 'showWarnings' flag in the OBJLoader.

    • Method Detail

      • loadModel

        public TriMesh loadModel(java.lang.String modelFilename)
        loadModel receives a String, assumed to be the name of a file containing a 3D model in WaveFront OBJ format; it reads the OBJ file and returns a TriMesh object containing the OBJ model data. Refer to the comments at the beginning of the OBJLoader class for assumptions and constraints regarding the processing of OBJ files by the loadModel() method.
        Specified by:
        loadModel in interface IModelLoader
        Parameters:
        modelFilename - The name of a file containing a model description
        Returns:
        A TriMesh containing the model

      • setVerbose

        public void setVerbose(boolean onOff)
        Enables/disables the 'verbose' flag in the OBJLoader. When 'verbose' is true, diagnostic and trace messages are displayed on the console; setting 'verbose' false suppresses output of such messages. The default setting for 'verbose' is false.
        Parameters:
        onOff - - the new value for the 'verbose' flag

      • setShowWarnings

        public void setShowWarnings(boolean onOff)
        Enables/disables the 'showWarnings' flag in the OBJLoader. When 'showWarnings' is true, warning messages are displayed on the console when the OBJLoader encounters unexpected issues (such as unrecognized commands in the input file). Setting 'showWarnings' false suppresses output of such messages. The default setting for 'showWarnings' is true.
        Parameters:
        onOff - - the new value for the 'showWarnings' flag
